captions.text: Pedalling is something most of us do without even thinking about it. But if that's you, then you're
missing a trick. Like most things in cycling, there's a technique to doing it well.
There's a well-worn phrase, which is to pedal in circles. Essentially this means that
you should think about using all 360 degrees of the pedal stroke,
not just pressing down at the beginning of the stroke.

The key is to eliminate dead spots in
the circle by peddling all the way
through. In practice then, when you get to the bottom of the pedal stroke, you should
pull your foot back
and then up.

The technique here feels like scraping
your foot back. You should feel this effort in your
hamstrings at the back of your legs.
When your pedal moves into the final 'up' phase of the stroke, the feeling is one of
lifting your knees
by recruiting your hip flexors.

This action doesn't add much in terms of
power to the pedal stroke, but it's fundamental to making it a smooth action.
fundamental to making a smooth action.
A good was of becoming familiar with the phases of the pedal stroke is to slow
the movement down.
Ride up a hill and select a much larger gear than is comfortable. Pedal at around 40RPM
with your hands resting lightly on the bars and your upper body
still.

When doing this, it should really clear when
you have a naturally strong surge in the

pedal stroke and where the dead spots are
as you struggle to turn the pedals.

Practicing with a slow cadence that you
can concentrate much more recruiting the

right muscles to help with the full
pedal stroke than if you were pedaling
at 90rpm.

When you're familiar with the feeling of
a full pedal stroke, it's time to smooth
things out.

Mountain bikers know all about this, as when on
loose surfaces it's key to prevent any

surges in power in order to maintain
traction. Try to avoid stamping on the
pedals.

It can help to only think about the
second half of the pedal stroke.

The principle is similar when riding out of
the saddle, except you won't be able to

perform a scraping action at the bottom
of the stroke. Lift your feet on the

upstroke to unweight them, and if you're really
putting out a lot of power pull up as
well with your hamstrings and hip flexors.
It also counters the effect of the downstroke

which prevents you pulling too much on
the handle bars.

It should be possible to transfer maximum
power out of the saddle without yanking on
the bars.
The reality is that few few pros pull up much on the pedals

but it's the action that everyone should
aim to do. Some power meters allow you to see
real-time power outputs during a stroke, such as a Wattbike. This can really help with
training for a full and smooth pedalling action.

Make sure that your saddle is at the right height.
It is impossible to peddle smoothly if you're
seat is too high, and it's much harder to recruit the right muscles if your seat is too low.
Practice on a turbo or rollers by pedalling one-legged. Even riding rollers with two legs

means you have to be super smooth, and it's a
great way to learn, but doing it one-legged

really works all the muscles needed
and if done enough can hard-wire into your
brain the pattern of muscle recruitment.
Try some slow-cadence drills that will teach you where the dead spots in the pedal
stroke are, and what action helps to get you over it. Keep your upper body motionless and hands
resting on the bars to make sure your legs are doing all the work.

title: How To Pedal Like A Pro

comments.text:

scraping your foot along the ground but more of a "try to knee yourself in 
the face on the upstroke..  i suppose shiny soles are preferable to a

comments.author: jonmarc peterson

comments.text:
I ride a Catrike so am not in the same league as you roadie types. 3 wheels 
are slower than two except for downhills. That being said I use clip in 
pedals and have found that using as much of the stroke as possible is 
clearly more effective for me - pushing and pulling the pedals gives me 
smoother and more powerful stroke period. I am more attuned to my cadence 
and what gear I am in now. I don't have to worry about my upper body moving 
to much in my seat since I am reclined. I feel my hips and other muscles 
strengthening as I ride more and further. I think the video is helpful to 
most folks. Thanks for posting and get out there and ride!﻿
comments.author: James Andrews

comments.text:
GSN needs to attend a British Cycling Coaching seminar. The BCF coach's at 
Manchester say don't concentrate on pulling up on the pedal stroke. Only 
concentrate on the downstroke no more.﻿
comments.author: Johnny Hewison

comments.text:
+David Williams the results were not based upon theory! The results were 
based upon scientific evidence gathered using SRM's. The results were also 
backed-up by tests conducted by Dr Aurial Forrester (The creator of SRM) 
Simon Jones (Head BC Coach) (Now Team Sky as of 2014) clearly stated that 
you should only concentrate on the down-stroke.
comments.author: Johnny Hewison

comments.text:
BCF coaches coach purely on theory though, you're watching a video with two 
guys who used to ride for SKY, a team that perfectly mixes theory with 
practicality to produce the best results, and in practice, pulling up makes 
sense, especially when pushing any higher than 200 watts because then if 
you don't pull up you'll be raising off the saddle every pedal stroke
comments.author: David Williams

comments.text:
And I don't see the point in having to eliminate dead spots in my pedal 
stroke as I only ever do no more than 30 miles at a time, and most of the 
power(if not all of it) comes from the down stroke. I think that for short 
distances using the full bicycle pedal stroke is counterproductive even as 
most victories in short time trials belong to the person with the most 
powerful pedal stroke of which the cyclist that derives close to 100percent 
of their power from the down stroke will win most if not all of the time.﻿

back as I am only around 150 pounds or so compared to those cyclists that

comments.text:
How To Pedal Like A Pro

There is a technique to pedalling efficiently and smoothly, but many people 
ride without giving it a second thought. In this video, we explain how to 
get the most out of your pedal stroke with a few simple tips from the pros. 
Follow GCN on Youtube: 

Firstly, we look at eliminating dead spots in the pedal stroke. Scraping 
back with your foot at the base of the pedal stroke, and then pulling up 
with your hip flexors. 

We cover the differences between in and out of the saddle, and give tips on 
how to get the most out of your pedal stroke when out of the saddle too. 

We also pass on hard earned Pro Tips, pedalling training drills, riding 
with a slow cadence and also riding one legged. 

All this and more, straight from the pros. ﻿
comments.author: Gestosa António

comments.text:
I've seen a lot of articles actually denying this, telling that you should 
only press down en pull back, but not pull upwards. I have no clue who to 
believe or what to do. I've been pedalling in the 'standard' way ever since 
I started, only pressing down and keeping my feet horizontal as much as 
possible. Anyone got any answers to what technique I should use?﻿
comments.author: Meneer

comments.text:
Like you've experienced, pulling up is hard to sustain for long periods. 
One key advantage of pulling up is that it does give you more power. I 
assume a good cyclist would know when to exert the extra effort for that 
extra power and when to be on cruise to conserve energy for later in the 
ride.
comments.author: 08Ultrasonic

comments.text:
So, it's better to only press down, especially in longer trainings I 
suppose. I already tried pulling upwards whilst riding, but next to the 
fact that I got tired earlier, it also doens't feel natural.
comments.author: Meneer

comments.text:
The reasoning for this is that more energy is exerted whilst pulling up 
when compared to the energy produced by the muscles. So whilst pulling up 
produces more power, it also drains you, the rider a lot quicker. This is 
because the main primary muscles in your legs are more efficient than the 
secondary muscles used to pull your leg back up.
comments.author: 08Ultrasonic

comments.author: arno bracke

comments.text:
+arno bracke youre welcome
perfect pedalling doesnt mean to go fast but to use the best biomechanical 
force/power efficency which is way better when you push/pull with the heel 
because you need less mucle power than generating force with the forefoot.
To go fast in sprint you need to flex of course all your leg and 
feet muscles for maximal strength-stability which is biomechanically 
concentrated on your ball of the foot = jumping = forefoot pedalling.
comments.author: Johnny Good

comments.text:
That's bullshit actually...
You go way more faster when you use your forefoot, also you can ride on 
souplesse which means way less energy loss...

comments.author: Conor Maher

comments.text:
What works for me is to spin at all spots in the stroke, but only do it so 
much. Like, the upward lifting is only light enough to make the weight of 
my thigh 0 and make the joints loose and move with the stroke instead of 
providing resistance. I also sort of push over the top of the stroke so 
that the action I get with my thigh gives as much as possible. I also make 
sure to loosen any muscles I'm not using. At high cadence I "stamp" as in, 
put out sharp bursts from the thighs.
comments.author: Opus 32

comments.text: I passed someone with one leg. Who do you think felt like the retard?
comments.author: Opus 32

comments.text:
Reality is that this advice is a BS, pros don't pull up the pedals. There 
is a study about this exact matter. When they pull the pedals, they provide 
little bit more power, yet they use much more energy and oxygen to provide 
that little extra power and soon they become exhausted. And this is obvious 
without a study if you think about it. In Cycling you don't need big 
muscles, you need much oxygen though. This pulling action in essence makes 
your pushing muslces bigger, therefore less effficient.
comments.author: Exmerch

fatigue sets in, you will misfire making this the worst possible advice.

comments.text:
I've heard that pulling the pedal up is less than good for the Achilles 
tendon since it is not "designed" to be pulled on in that fashion. 
Therefore "scraping the foot" is as much as one should for an effective 
pedal.
comments.author: Sebastian Aske

comments.text: wow thanks this helped me so much
comments.author: David Kronen
